content.raw:
When I think of direction, I usually think of a normalized vector. Do you think it would make sense to normalize it here?

Also, all other functions seem to be spelled out, so maybe a better name is `Direction()`?
content.html:
When I think of direction, I usually think of a normalized vector. Do you think it would make sense to normalize it here?

Also, all other functions seem to be spelled out, so maybe a better name is Direction()?

content.raw:
I prefer to leave it unnormalized since it can be used as a component of the parametric line equation pt = dir * t + pts[0], where 0 < t < 1.
I will rename it to Direction()
content.html: I prefer to leave it unnormalized since it can be used as a component of the parametric line equation pt = dir * t + pts[0], where 0 < t < 1. I will rename it to Direction()

content.raw:
I see what you mean. Perhaps the function can be renamed to something which suggests the magnitude is maintained, I can't think of a good name now though... 

When I hear direction, I imagine for example that two parallel lines have the same direction, so I'd expect to have  `Line3(0, 0, 1, 0, 0, 2).Direction() == Line3(1, 1, 6, 1, 1, 16).Direction()`. Maybe that's just me?

Maybe in your formula you could use `line.Direction()*line.Length()`? Or to avoid the extra back and forth of the computation, just do the subtraction?
content.html:
I see what you mean. Perhaps the function can be renamed to something which suggests the magnitude is maintained, I can't think of a good name now though...

When I hear direction, I imagine for example that two parallel lines have the same direction, so I'd expect to have Line3(0, 0, 1, 0, 0, 2).Direction() == Line3(1, 1, 6, 1, 1, 16).Direction(). Maybe that's just me?

Maybe in your formula you could use line.Direction()*line.Length()? Or to avoid the extra back and forth of the computation, just do the subtraction?

content.raw: Sure, that sounds reasonable. I will use line.Direction()*line.Length()
content.html: Sure, that sounds reasonable. I will use line.Direction()*line.Length()

content.raw:
Interesting thing to bring up, segments defined in "opposite directions". 

To be honest I don't know how I feel about this whole direction thing, I'm not sure this really applies to lines / line segments as they don't really have a "start" and an "end", just two points. But maybe I'm thinking too much about the mathematical aspects of it and too little about making useful functions. I'm eager to hear what others have to say about this.
content.html:
Interesting thing to bring up, segments defined in "opposite directions".

To be honest I don't know how I feel about this whole direction thing, I'm not sure this really applies to lines / line segments as they don't really have a "start" and an "end", just two points. But maybe I'm thinking too much about the mathematical aspects of it and too little about making useful functions. I'm eager to hear what others have to say about this.

content.raw: I just created issue #26 somewhat related to this.
content.html: I just created issue #26 somewhat related to this.

content.raw:
I think its fine for a line segment to have a direction. Parametric line equations have a direction and a direction is often useful for doing ray tracing and intersection tests. 

Directed Line Segments are also a recognized geometric object: http://www.ck12.org/book/CK-12-Trigonometry-Concepts/r2/section/5.13/
content.html:
I think its fine for a line segment to have a direction. Parametric line equations have a direction and a direction is often useful for doing ray tracing and intersection tests.

Directed Line Segments are also a recognized geometric object: http://www.ck12.org/book/CK-12-Trigonometry-Concepts/r2/section/5.13/

Can you make change this function to:

public: void Set(const double _x1, const double _y1, const double _x2, const double _y2, const double _z=0)
{
  this->pts[0].Set(_x1, _y1, z);
  this->pts[1].Set(_x2, _y2, z);
}

content.raw: It was more useful to have the z value present. All that you need to do is change the doxygen comment to specify what the z value does.

content.raw: ok i added it back in
Do we need this default constructor?
It is useful, if you just want to create a line3, but not sure what to set the values until later (example: a vector of line3 objects)
content.html: It is useful, if you just want to create a line3, but not sure what to set the values until later (example: a vector of line3 objects)

content.raw: The compiler will create a default constructor for you if it's not present . You can remove this since you are not doing any special in the constructor.
content.html: The compiler will create a default constructor for you if it's not present . You can remove this since you are not doing any special in the constructor.

content.raw: The compiler will only do that if no other constructors are present. You still need to explicitly specify a default constructor since Line3 has other constructors.
content.html: The compiler will only do that if no other constructors are present. You still need to explicitly specify a default constructor since Line3 has other constructors.

content.raw: Yes, but we are referring to: `public: Line3() = default;`
content.html: Yes, but we are referring to: public: Line3() = default;

I have changed it to 

 public: Line3() = default;

content.raw: If `_z` is an optional parameter you might pass a non-zero `z` value and the Z coordinate of the points wouldn't be 0. Is this OK we should probably rephrase the description of the method. If the idea is to force `z` to be 0, then we can remove the `_z` parameter and hardcode a `0` in the `Set`s functions.
content.html: If _z is an optional parameter you might pass a non-zero z value and the Z coordinate of the points wouldn't be 0. Is this OK we should probably rephrase the description of the method. If the idea is to force z to be 0, then we can remove the _z parameter and hardcode a 0 in the Sets functions.
